sect1.sect2:
System Video Input
&app; can capture video from a video capture card through v4l2, from IIDC camera or DV camera (also called iLink). DV cameras and decks have a high latency (often between 150 and 250ms) and should not be the video input of choise for low latency requirements.
Video4Linux >
Plug in the video camera, for this, refer to our Hardware Setup Page
Now we will modify our video settings for your specific needs.
Firewire (DV or IIDC) Video Input
* The current user must be part of the disk and video groups. If that is not the case, then the system administrator must add the "user" to the "disk" group (as shown above)
On Karmic Koala, you have to fix devices attribution for raw1394. Create a udev rule to change group of /dev/raw1394 device: echo 'KERNEL=="raw1394", NAME="raw1394", GROUP="disk"' | sudo tee -a /etc/udev/rules.d/99-raw1394.rules sudo /etc/init.d/udev restart
Furthermore, on all distributions, it is advisable to load the raw1394 module even if no dc1394 cameras are present so that calls to libdc (i.e. milhouse --list-cameras) won't error out. To do this, add raw1394 to the /etc/modules file: sudo modprobe raw1394 echo "raw1394" | sudo tee -a /etc/modules
See
this bug report for further information.
You can test the DV camera with:
gst-launch dv1394src ! dvdemux ! dvdec ! xvimagesink
